div.p: Holy Bullinger, I wish you eternal salvation in Christ our Savior.
You may wonder why I dare to trouble you with my letters.
Forgive me, I will write briefly.
Not long ago I was in Zürich, where I could pour out all my concerns; you have the remains of the same person among you.

Therefore, Zürich often comes to my mind. But why should I babble about what I am thinking? Martyr lives; may Zürich live and prosper happily. And so that the memory of Zürich's kindness to me does not perish along with Martyr, I now address you. A small dwelling was once given to me in Zürich: if God were to grant my wishes now, I would earnestly seek it again. Perhaps I am complaining about myself while wishing for such things; I do not deny it.
But since the glory of Christ, our Lord, is to be sought above all, I abandon my requests, as far as they concern me.
In this matter (in seeking a little lodging) I do not wish to trouble you again.
Oh, if only it were granted to reach the mansions prepared for us by Christ the Lord in heaven! Meanwhile, most holy father, I commend our England and myself to your prayers.
Things are going badly in England; I fear worse, not to say the worst.
But in the meantime, we must serve Christ the Lord.
Happy is he whom our Christ calls into service.
Therefore, keep England most recommended in your prayers and also remember me.
As a perpetual sign of my love for you, I send Oxford gloves through Mr. Blaurer, your countryman.
They will grow old; yet may the love of England and me never grow old with you.
Farewell and live most happily in the Lord, dearest father. Oxford, July 26, 1563.
Greet, I pray, in my name and my wife's, Julius Terentianus. To the excellent man Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, most faithful preacher of the divine word.
